posts.name: Anika
posts.cooked: The text describes the creation of patterns for reversible U-shaped bumpers made from scratch. Instructions provided may lack clarity and are offered as a general guide. Clarifications are added, noting that the not-sewn end must be opened for staples. Images illustrating the patterns and examples of completed bumpers are referenced. A note explains that differences in bumper design considerations affect the pattern fitting. Completed 2024 bumpers are showcased through images. Further information on making reversible bumpers is available upon request.

posts.name: Zakk Jackson
posts.cooked:
Here’s the cleaned-up version of the provided text based on your instructions:

**Final Answer:**

Yes please, I would love a guide on this.

posts.name: Anika
posts.cooked:
Here is a diagram for finding all of the dimensions you need:

A few notes:
- The seam allowance (G) is crucial—it provides space for sewing and is where staples attach the fabric to your bumper backer. While it doesn’t have to be exactly 2 inches, you can always cut extra material if needed.

We didn’t measure the dimensions ourselves. Instead, we traced one face of our built bumpers onto the back of the fabric repeatedly until the entire pattern was mapped out.

The angles on the bottom should be 45 degrees. To achieve this, connect the traced lengths of the inner (E + F) and outer (C + D) parts.

posts.name: Anika
posts.cooked: I'm realizing how little sense this makes without context, so a full explanation will come eventually. (Google drawings may not have been the right choice for the diagrams)

posts.name: Patrick
posts.cooked: There is a minimal difference between regular and color change fabric patterns when discussing sewn seams versus folding extra fabric. The only distinctions are the presence of one additional seam along the fold and reducing the staple allowance from full size to half-inch for one-sided sewing. Sheet metal CAD is by far the simplest method for creating bumper fabric patterns, and I prefer folding the fabric end to end rather than top to bottom when making color change bumpers.

posts.name: Anika
posts.cooked:
Here is the cleaned-up version of the text:

Skecthes of the same style of cover for a bunch of bumper shapes because I was bored. For me sheet metal CAD is by far the easiest way to make bumper fabric patterns and thanks!

posts.name: Kaden Morrison
posts.cooked: We were also able to make 1-piece reversible bumpers for this year, which are not as difficult to make with our instructions to assist you.
